column6: An introduction to the history of art emphasizing analysis and interpretation of visual art forms. The course will also focus on the functions and meaning of Western and non-Western art traditions. No credit for art majors.

column2: ART HISTORY I: ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL ART
column6: Examination and interpretation of the major monuments of Western art and architecture from Paleolithic art to late Gothic art. The impact of non-Western traditions will be included as appropriate.

column2: ART HISTORY II: RENAISSANCE TO MODERN ART
column6: Major movements and artists in painting, sculpture and allied arts of Europe and America from early Renaissance in Italy until the present day. The impact of non- Western traditions will be included as appropriate.

column2: ART OF AFRICA, OCEANIA AND THE AMERICAS
column6: Stylistic and historical investigation of the art and architecture of the traditional societies of Africa, Oceania and the Americas within an art historical and cross- cultural perspective.
Painting, sculpture and allied arts in the United States and Europe from 1940 to the present.

column2: RESEARCH AND WRITING IN ART HISTORY
column6: Introduction to the basic techniques and resources for art history research. Provides assistance in the preparation of research papers and critical essays required by upper-division art history courses.
Examination of sources and styles of Chinese art from prehistoric to recent times.
Examination of sources and styles of Japanese art, from prehistoric to recent times.
Arts, crafts and architecture of the western Sudanic and Guinea Coast areas of West Africa from prehistoric times to the present.
Study of the arts, crafts and architecture of Nigeria from prehistoric times to the present.
Comparative study of the arts, crafts and architecture of Central Africa from prehistoric times to the present.
(Cross-listed with CLAS 41401, CLAS 51401 and ARTH 52031) Greek art and architecture from earliest times through Hellenistic period with special attention given to recent archaeological discoveries.

(Cross-listed with CLAS 41402, CLAS 51402 and ARTH 52032) Introduction to archaeology of Roman world. Emphasis on discoveries and impact on study of Italic, Etruscan and Roman art, architecture and sculpture through Imperial period.
Emphasis on major period of Medieval art (Byzantine, Carolingian, Ottoman, Romanesque and Gothic) treating iconographic themes and styles in a variety of media.
An examination of the development of European Gothic art from the 12th century to the 15th century. Emphasis on the ties to contemporary philosophical and literary developments.
Study of development of major themes in Italian art from 1400 until c. 1550 emphasizing achievements of the masters and analyzing major ideas and theories of the period.
Study of stylistic and iconographic questions and technique in Northern panel painting, as well as other arts in Northern Europe.

column2: THE HIGH RENAISSANCE AND MANNERISM IN ITALY
column6: Covers late 15th century and 16th century painting, sculpture and architecture in Italy. Following discussion of the High Renaissance masters, students examine the works collectively known as the Mannerists. Course gives students a firm grounding in the manifold artistic activity of the 16th century.

Course provides a survey of Venetian painting, sculpture and architecture from the late 1300's to the late 1500's. Upon completion students have a comprehension of the interrelationship of Venetian art with its unique environment and society.
Study of the origins of Baroque art in Italy and its spread throughout Flanders, the Netherlands, France and Spain.
Selected studies in late 18th-century and 19th-century British, French, German and Spanish art and architecture within the broader context of Western culture and ideas.
In-depth study of American painting, sculpture, graphic art, architecture and allied arts from the Civil War to 1940.
Study of painting, sculpture, architecture and allied arts in Europe from 1880 to 1940.
Examines the role of European roots in the formation of American art. The complex issues and identities artists faced as a result of the expatriate experience are addressed.
A survey of the major movement of the sixties decade, with primary emphasis on the United States.
Traces the arts of visual communication from their origins to current trends and practices with an emphasis on theory and aesthetics.
Chronological survey of printmaking (engraving, etching, lithography, etc.) From 1400 to the present emphasizing its technical and stylistic evolution.

column2: HISTORY OF THE DECORATIVE AND APPLIED ARTS
column6: Historical and critical examination of decorative and applied arts and their relationship to the Western societies which produced them.

column4: Junior standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Open format course with topics announced in advance. Designed to allow detailed examination of selected topics.

column4: Junior or senior standing and ARTH 42072.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) A supervised internship in a regional art museum emphasizing the practical application of museological principles and practices.

(Repeatable for credit) Upper-division discussion and lecture course whose content changes in accordance with the interest and competence of faculty. Precise title to be inserted in Schedule of Classes.
(Repeatable for credit) Directed independent study with art history faculty.

column2: FIELD EXPERIENCE: TRAVEL STUDY IN ART HISTORY
column4: Major in art history or special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Travel-based study/field experience in art history to and at a site or sites away from Kent State University. The primary benefit will be the observation and study of works of art first hand, in addition to the presentation and discussion of historical and contextual factors. Time is made available for individual investigation of specific works sites.
Arts, crafts and architecture of the Western Sudanic and Guinea Coast areas of West Africa from prehistoric times to the present.
Study of the arts, crafts and architecture of Nigeria from prehistoric times to present.
Study of the arts, c rafts and architecture of Central Africa from prehistoric times to present.

(Cross-listed with CLAS 41401, CLAS 51401 and ARTH 42031) Greek art and architecture from earliest times through the Hellenistic period with special attention given to recent archaeological discoveries.

(Cross-listed with CLAS 41402, CLAS 51402 and ARTH 42032) Introduction to archaeology of the Roman world. Emphasis on discoveries and impact on the study of Italic, Etruscan and Roman art, architecture and sculpture through Imperial period.
Emphasis on major periods of Medieval art (Byzantine, Carolingian, Ottoman, Romanesque and Gothic), treating iconographic themes and styles in a variety of media.

An examination of the development of European Gothic art from the 12th to the 15th centuries. Students will research specific works of art. The course will put emphasis on contemporary historical philosophical and literary figures.
Study of development of major themes in Italian art from 1400 until about 1550, emphasizing achievements of the masters and analyzing major ideas and theories of the period.
Study of stylistic and iconographic questions and technique in northern panel painting, as well as other arts in Northern Europe.

column2: THE HIGH RENAISSANCE AND MANNERISM IN ITALY
column6: Covers late 15th century and 16th century painting, sculpture and architecture in Italy. Following discussion of the High Renaissance masters students examine the works collectively known as the Mannerists. Course gives students a firm grounding in the manifold artistic activity of the 16th century.

Course provides a survey of Venetian painting, sculpture and architecture from the late 1300's to the late 1500's. Upon completion students will have a comprehension of Venetian art with its unique environment and society.
A study of the origins of Baroque art in Italy and its spread throughout Flanders, the Netherlands, France and Spain.
Selected studies in late 18th-century and 19th-century painting, sculpture architecture and allied arts of England, France, Germany and Spain.

column2: AMERICAN FILM, PHOTOGRAPHY, ART AND IDEAS
column6: Key examples of photography from the 19th century to present day.
A study of painting, sculpture, architecture and allied arts in Europe from 1880 to 1940.
Examines the role of European roots in the formation of American art. The complex issues and identities artists faced as a result of the expatriate experience are addressed.
A study of painting, sculpture and allied arts in the United States and Europe from 1940 to the present.
A survey of major movements of the sixties decade, with primary emphasis on the United States.
This course traces the arts of visual communication from their origins to current trends and practices with an emphasis on theory and aesthetics.

column2: HISTORY OF DECORATIVE AND APPLIED ARTS
column6: Historical and critical examination of decorative and applied arts and their relationship to Western societies which produced them.
(Repeatable for credit) Discussion and lecture course whose topic changes in accordance with the interest and competence of the faculty. Precise title will be inserted in schedule of classes.
(Repeatable for credit) Directed independent study with art history faculty.

column2: FIELD EXPERIENCE: TRAVEL STUDY IN ART HISTORY
column4: Graduate standing in art history or special approval of instructor.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Travel-based study/field experience in art history to and at a site or sites away from Kent State University. The primary benefit will be the observation and study of works of art first hand, in addition to the presentation and discussion of historical and contextual factors. Time is made available for individual investigation of specific works sites.
In-depth study of American painting, sculpture, graphic and allied arts from 1860 to 1940.
A chronological survey of printmaking (engraving, etching, lithography, etc.) From 1400 to the present emphasizing its technical and stylistic evolution.

(Repeatable for credit) Discussion and lecture course whose topic changes in accordance with the interest and competence of the faculty. Special focus on problems and issues in the different areas of the discipline.
(Repeatable for a maximum of 9 credit hours) The course content changes each semester according to the topic, entailing discussion and lectures on specific problems issues and areas in art history.
(Repeatable for credit) Independent research open only to art history graduate students who have completed course Requirements for the Master of Arts degree.
